CARDINAL . On DATE , ORG ( FAC ) in its constitutional jurisdiction found a violation of LAW , in that the applicants had been denied access to court . Indeed , it was only the ORG who could institute proceedings according to domestic law . The fact that recently the law had been applied to allow the applicants to take up proceedings requesting a court to order the latter to act within a time - limit did not detract from the fact that it ultimately remained the duty of the ORG to take up these proceedings , and the affected individuals had no obligation to solicit such an action . Moreover , even in the event that ownership of land was at issue , it referred to ORG earlier reasoning in this respect ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) and , moreover , considered that the ORG could have instituted proceedings by means of a curator . It awarded them LAW by way of damages and dismissed the remainder of their claims . It held that the taking of the CARDINAL plots of land which were being used for the GPE had been in the public interest , the latter being an important economic venture for the country . The fact that it was later privatised did not take away the element of public interest , despite the fact that the deed of expropriation had not yet been finalised . Moreover , the CARDINAL of the CARDINAL plots which was outside the GPE zone which had remained unused could have been used for future development . It failed to take cognisance of the complaint regarding compensation , holding that this had not yet been determined by the LAB . As to the complaint about the length of the proceedings , namely DATE for the ORG to initiate proceedings , the court held that apart from the fact that this had been related to the previous complaint under LAW , the provision referred to proceedings which had already begun and had taken an unreasonable time to be finally decided ; therefore it was not applicable in the present case which was still pending . Lastly , since the law had been changed , the composition of the ORG clearly satisfied the LAW .

CARDINAL . On appeal , by a decision of CARDINAL DATE ORG reversed the said judgment in part . It confirmed that there had been a violation of LAW in so far as the applicants had been deprived of access to a court but only from the period starting on DATE , the date when GPE introduced the right of individual petition . It also considered that there had been a violation of the reasonable time principle DATE and DATE , the date when the compensation proceedings were initiated . It had regard however to the fact that the applicants were also to blame for not having taken up the civil remedy available to solicit the ORG earlier than they had done . Moreover , no proof had been supplied that the proceedings currently pending before the LAB were not satisfying the reasonable time requirement .

CARDINAL . The Constitutional Court further found a violation of LAW No . CARDINAL to the Convention . Holding that the public interest had to persist from DATE of the taking to the date of the conclusion of the act of expropriation , it considered that even the land which had remained unused had been taken for such a purpose , since the GPE could reasonably expand to cover such land . Moreover , the privatisation of the GPE did not detract from the public interest involved . The court further confirmed that it was not in a position to consider the amount of compensation which had yet to be decided by the ORG . However , the fact that the process of expropriation had taken DATE had caused the applicants to suffer a disproportionate burden , constituting a violation of the applicants’ property rights .

CARDINAL . The Constitutional Court reduced the amount of compensation to ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL , covering moral damage in relation to the said violations and confirmed the rejection of the remaining complaints .

In PERSON vs PERSON u l - Kummissarju ta l - Artijiet ( Rikors Nru DATE , DATE ) ORG held , after giving an overview of the applicable principles under LAW to the LAW , that whenever the process by which an individual is divested of his property is not concluded , the interference therefore remains CARDINAL of control of use , the ORG has the obligation to release the property to its rightful owners as soon as it transpires that there no longer exist grounds on which the ORG had originally , validly and justifiably taken the measure by which the owner ’s use was restricted . It was for the Government to prove that both at the time of the Governor ’s declaration and throughout the proceedings until the transfer of the property concluding the expropriation there existed a public interest for the taking of the property .

CARDINAL . In this case the evidence revealed that for DATE the competent authorities had actively considered releasing the property to its rightful owners , as it was no longer needed for the purposes for which it had originally been taken . Moreover , DATE had passed since the date of the declaration and the present application , and thus the lack of public interest was evident . ORG noted that a general interest had indeed existed at the time of the declaration . However , it subsequently emerged that PERSON property would not have been used for that purpose and therefore the ORG should have returned the said property . Failure to comply with this latter obligation amounted to a breach of the applicants’ property rights under the LAW .
